title: What’s the big deal with gluten? - William D. Chey

multiple-choice.question: What is gluten?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of sugar found in wheat and other foods

options.label: B
options.text: An insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins named gliadin and glutenin

options.label: C
options.text: A type of fiber found in certain grains

options.label: D
options.text: A type of enzyme that breaks down proteins

multiple-choice.question: Which grains are gluten typically found in?
What is the primary function of gluten in food?

options.label: C
options.text: To give food its elastic consistency and chewiness

multiple-choice.question: What is wheat allergy?

options.label: A
options.text: An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine

options.label: B
options.text: A condition where the immune system mounts an allergic response to wheat proteins

options.label: C
options.text: A type of intolerance to wheat sugars

multiple-choice.question: What is celiac disease?

options.label: B
options.text: An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine

options.label: C
options.text: A type of intolerance to wheat sugars

multiple-choice.question: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is non-celiac gluten sensitivity?

options.label: B
options.text: An inherited disease that causes inflammation and damage to the small intestine

options.label: C
options.text: A condition where people experience symptoms when eating foods with gluten, but do not have celiac disease or a wheat allergy

options.label: D
options.text: A type of intolerance to wheat sugars

multiple-choice.question: How is non-celiac gluten sensitivity diagnosed?

options.label: C
options.text: Based on the development of symptoms and improvement on a gluten-free diet

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where a person believes something will have a positive effect, and because of that belief, it does

options.label: C
options.text: A type of intolerance to wheat sugars

options.label: A
options.text: Because gluten is the primary cause of symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Because wheat is the primary grain that contains gluten

options.label: C
options.text: Because the problems people develop when eating wheat and other grains are not exclusively due to gluten

options.label: D
options.text: Because gluten is found in all types of grains

title: Will future spacecraft fit in our pockets? - Dhonam Pemba

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the main advantages of using microspacecraft for space exploration?

options.label: A
options.text: They can carry more fuel and supplies.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They can only be used for short-duration missions.

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Sophisticated electronic sensors that measure various parameters.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the challenges of propelling microspacecraft?

options.label: A
options.text: They require a large engine and tons of fuel.

options.label: B
options.text: They need a specialized propulsion system due to their small size.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only be propelled using solar sails.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not require any propulsion system.

options.label: A
options.text: It uses a large engine to generate thrust.

options.label: B
options.text: It shoots out charged particles to generate momentum.

options.label: C
options.text: It uses solar sails to propel the spacecraft.

options.label: D
options.text: It relies on gravity to propel the spacecraft.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the metal grid in the microfluidic electrospray propulsion system?

options.label: B
options.text: It sets up an electric field between the grid and the plate.

options.label: C
options.text: It pulls the molten metal upwards.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no role in the propulsion system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the electric field overcoming the surface tension in the microfluidic electrospray propulsion system?

options.label: A
options.text: The indium melts and capillary action draws the liquid metal up the needles.

options.label: B
options.text: The spacecraft is propelled in the opposite direction.

options.label: C
options.text: Positively charged ions shoot off at speeds of tens of kilometers per second.

multiple-choice.question: What is the advantage of the microfluidic electrospray propulsion system over traditional rocket engines?

options.label: D
options.text: It is more fuel-efficient and produces less exhaust.

multiple-choice.question: What is the predicted outcome of using micropropulsion systems in the next ten years?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Microspacecraft will be limited to exploring only the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: D

What was the result of Alessandro Volta's groundbreaking experiment using a stack of alternating layers of zinc and copper?

What is the standard unit of electric potential named after Alessandro Volta?
Why do batteries eventually die?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they run out of electrons

options.label: B
options.text: Because the metal oxidizes and there is a finite supply of metal

options.label: C
options.text: Because the chemical solution dries out

options.label: D
options.text: Because the battery is not rechargeable

multiple-choice.question: How do rechargeable batteries temporarily solve the problem of a finite supply of metal?

options.label: A
options.text: By making the oxidation-reduction process irreversible

options.label: B
options.text: By making the oxidation-reduction process reversible

options.label: C
options.text: By increasing the amount of metal in the battery

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing the amount of metal in the battery

multiple-choice.question: Why do even rechargeable batteries eventually die?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the repetition of the oxidation-reduction process causes imperfections and irregularities in the metal's surface

options.label: B
options.text: Because the battery is not properly maintained

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They will be light and thin sheets that operate on the principles of quantum physics

options.label: D
options.text: They will be expensive and inefficient

options.label: A
options.text: Plugging one battery into another to charge it

options.label: B
options.text: Using solar panels to charge the battery

options.label: C

title: Debunking the myths of OCD - Natascha M. Santos

multiple-choice.question: What is the common misconception about people who like to meticulously organize their things or keep their hands clean?
What are the two aspects of obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)?
What is the main difference between people suffering from OCD and those who are just meticulous or hygiene obsessed?

options.label: C
options.text: The diagnostic criteria of having little or no control over obsessive thoughts and compulsive behaviors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most common image of OCD in popular culture?
What is a common manifestation of obsessions in OCD?
Do individuals with OCD understand that they are acting irrationally?

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, many individuals with OCD understand the relationship between their obsessions and compulsions.

options.label: D
options.text: Only some individuals with OCD understand.

multiple-choice.question: What is considered to be the cause of OCD?

What is one of the effective treatments for OCD?

options.label: A
options.text: Medications that decrease serotonin in the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: Behavioral therapy that gradually desensitizes patients to their anxieties.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of future research into the brain and OCD?

options.label: B
options.text: A better understanding of the brain and the answers to the causes of OCD.

title: Sunlight is way older than you think - Sten Odenwald

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for light to travel from the surface of the Sun to Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: They gain energy and become shorter wavelength forms of light

options.label: B
options.text: They interact with matter and lose energy, becoming longer wavelength forms of light

multiple-choice.question: What is the initial form of light produced by nuclear reactions in the Sun's core?

options.label: A
options.text: It is absorbed by the proton

options.label: B
options.text: It is diverted in another direction

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the problem that describes the journey of a photon from the Sun's core to its surface?
What is the average distance between protons in the Sun, assuming they are evenly spread out?
Why is the initial calculation of 400 billion years for a photon to travel from the Sun's core to its surface incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: The Sun is not of uniform density and photons will miss quite a few protons between every collision

options.label: C
options.text: The photon's energy is too high

options.label: D
options.text: The photon's energy is too low

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated time it takes for a photon to travel from the Sun's core to its surface, based on a sophisticated solar interior model?

options.label: D
options.text: Around the same time when humans first started wearing clothes, about two ice ages ago
